review_blob: The deScription above is incorrect. The herb is coriander, not cilantro. But, it doesnt really matter as they put so little in that you cant taste it anyhow. They also put little to no salt in, so you cant really taste that either. That is, the two special qualities of a Gose are both missing from this beer. It is drinkable, but not a Gose.

I first tasted this beer 7-8 years ago at the Berlin beer festival. I thought it was a very nice beer and quite enjoyed it. Unfortunately, Ritterguts has changed its contract brewer and the recipe. The beer is quite simply no longer a Gose. It may come close to a Berliner Weie, but it lacks both the salt and coriander that are characteristic of a Gose. The beer is quite drinkable, but it is mis-labelled.

Is this beer a joke or satire? It has little to no aroma and tastes like sugar water. Save your money, this is a drain beer. And the deScription is a laugh! Dont these people know even the basics about Belgian beer?

Just a lovely beer. Taste is very similar to a good German Pilsener. In fact, I liked this better than Brands Urtype Pilsener. Colour, mouthfeel, aroma - all are on-target and together make a very tasty and enjoyable beer. Bottle bought in Amsterdam.

I dont what the other raters drank, but my bottle was close to perfect. The aroma, palate and taste were all delicious and in harmony. This is simply one of the best beers I have experienced. My only disappointment was that I had only one bottle of it.
beer_name: Fullers Past Masters XX Strong Ale

review_blob: Lovely beer. Well-balanced, very drinkable and thirst quenching. One of the best American beers I have sampled.
Tastes like a homebrewing experiment that failed. Flavours come from all over and crash in your mouth. Belgian-style? Why insult Belgian brewers with this sorry beer? Sampled from the bottle.

Ach! Is this nothing more than a marketing beer? Full of hops, yes, but what about balance? Why is there no malt presence? Or is it completely drowned in the hops? This is as close to a German pils as a plastic christmas tree is to the Schwartzwald. Tasted on tap in the US.

On tap. A professionally made, but nevertheless awful beer. Overloaded with Cascade (?) hops that hides any other flavours that may be present. If you can imagine, for example, pasta with a pineapple juice sauce, you might have some idea of how inappropriate the hop choice was.

This is not so much a beer as an experience. Your sitting in a London pub only days before WWI. The beer comes in a pint glass, light chocolate foam and very dark beer. The taste: this is what beer tasted like before the beer factory was invented after the next war. Very rich, full chocolate, coffee notes, very nice body. Complex. Perfectly balanced with both hops and malt harmonising beautifully with each other. Little to no taste of alcohol. Drunk at room temperature at de Wildeman approximately three weeks after bottling. Will almost certainly improve with age. The only negative: not enough bottles!

Tried two bottles: 2005 and 2004 (at Kulminator). The 2005 was OK visually, but over-the-top sweetness killed it for me. Generally a rich beer with fruit and chocolate notes and enough sugar to kill a tooth. The 2004 was less sweet, but everything else was also less. Not complex and not particularly tasty. Is this the most over-rated beer here?
